H0.text: Producers are the organisms that eat only plants.

H1.text: Omnivores are organisms that eat only plants.

H2.text: Herbivores are organisms that eat only plants.

H3.text: Scavengers are organisms that eat only plants.

A4.text: Autotrophs take energy from the environment in the form of sunlight or inorganic chemicals and use it to create fuel molecules such as carbohydrates.

A5.text: Heterotrophs – all animals, almost all fungi, as well as most bacteria and protozoa – depend on autotrophs, or primary producers, for the raw materials and fuel they need.

A6.text: Although cases exist of herbivores eating meat and carnivores eating plant matter, the classification 'omnivore' refers to the adaptation and main food source of the species in general

A7.text: An omnivore is an animal that eats both plant and animal matter

A8.text: Scavengers are animals that feed on dead and decaying organic matter.

A9.text: Animals that feed on dead plant material are called herbivorous scavengers.
